quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 3 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 3 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607045
entry.itemBody: Two years ago, a homeowner took out a $1 million home mortgage from a bank. The current principal on the loan is $750,000, and the homeowner has defaulted on the loan. Following foreclosure proceedings, the bank sells the property for $600,000 and is only entitled to use these funds to satisfy the loan obligation. The homeowner most likely had a:

answerFeedback.1324a787-6aaa-4f8a-b102-ccb45f3ded54: Correct because the bank does not have a claim against the borrower for the shortfall of $150,000 on the mortgage balance outstanding relative to the proceeds received from the property’s sale, indicating that the home mortgage is a non-recourse loan.
answerFeedback.aaf49fb2-e5c2-41c6-90ec-f52fda69dd42: Incorrect because in the case of a recourse loan the bank would have been entitled to make a claim for the shortfall of $150,000 against the borrower.
answerFeedback.c24ff3de-41e9-41ff-a4f8-752e68ffeb79: Incorrect because a bullet loan is a type of interest-only mortgage loan in which there are no principal payments over the term of the loan. The loan balance outstanding is less than the original mortgage amount, so it is unlikely that this was a bullet loan.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08909
entry.itemBody: Valuing private equity investments using estimated prices rather than market prices most likely causes an:

answerFeedback.2b4055bd-e77d-44e1-9cb8-a3d9433d1daa: Incorrect because these measures will be understated not overstated. Measuring historical private equity performance is challenging; as with hedge funds, which will be discussed later, private equity return indexes typically rely on self-reporting and are subject to survivorship, backfill, and other biases. This typically leads to an overstatement of returns. Moreover, prior to the global financial crisis of 2008–2009, in the absence of a liquidity event, private equity firms did not necessarily mark their investments to market. Failure to mark to market combined with the lag to mark investments due to inherent illiquidity will understate measures of volatility and correlations with other investments.
answerFeedback.9faef819-e0c7-49d3-b176-c691c2a045ee: Correct because measuring historical private equity performance is challenging; as with hedge funds, which will be discussed later, private equity return indexes typically rely on self-reporting and are subject to survivorship, backfill, and other biases. This typically leads to an overstatement of returns. Moreover, prior to the global financial crisis of 2008–2009, in the absence of a liquidity event, private equity firms did not necessarily mark their investments to market. Failure to mark to market combined with the lag to mark investments due to inherent illiquidity will understate measures of volatility and correlations with other investments.
answerFeedback.d98165cf-bbb1-4f40-98f4-967cf81c112f: Incorrect because both of these measures will be understated. Measuring historical private equity performance is challenging; as with hedge funds, which will be discussed later, private equity return indexes typically rely on self-reporting and are subject to survivorship, backfill, and other biases. This typically leads to an overstatement of returns. Moreover, prior to the global financial crisis of 2008–2009, in the absence of a liquidity event, private equity firms did not necessarily mark their investments to market. Failure to mark to market combined with the lag to mark investments due to inherent illiquidity will understate measures of volatility and correlations with other investments.

choices.itemBody: A. overestimation of both return volatility and the correlation of returns with traditional asset classes.
B. underestimation of both return volatility and the correlation of returns with traditional asset classes.
C. underestimation of return volatility and overestimation of the correlation of returns with traditional asset classes.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06701
entry.itemBody: A greenfield infrastructure investment is best described as an asset that has:

answerFeedback.2d6529c6-283e-44b3-856f-e916b738987e: Correct because greenfield investments entail developing new assets and new infrastructure.
answerFeedback.83a9a23f-3e18-4659-b92c-3801b54a7663: Incorrect because greenfield investments entail developing new assets and new infrastructure. An investment on an asset that has already been constructed is most likely considered a brownfield investment as those investments expand existing facilities and may involve privatization of public assets or a sale leaseback of completed greenfield projects.
answerFeedback.d0aa5473-f54d-454b-b0bd-0cc0ed1a9992: Incorrect because greenfield investments entail developing new assets and new infrastructure. An investment on an asset that has already been constructed is most likely considered a brownfield investment as those investments expand existing facilities and may involve privatization of public assets or a sale leaseback of completed greenfield projects.

choices.itemBody: C. reached the end of its useful life.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-CorpIssuers-Moustra-11
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? US commercial paper typically:

answerFeedback.0c223dd1-3b51-4b57-9d15-f1a30558cc80: Incorrect because commercial paper is a short-term, unsecured promissory note issued in the public market or via a private placement that represents a debt obligation of the issuer. Being unsecured, the issuer is not required to pledge collateral.
answerFeedback.47cbb244-a2a7-498a-919d-42580469ecef: Correct because credit rating agencies often require that commercial paper issuers secure a backup line of credit from banks.
answerFeedback.b3ce28ed-053f-4f39-a894-9e169db54702: Incorrect because maturities for US commercial paper typically range from a few days up to 270 days.

choices.itemBody: A. requires the issuer to pledge collateral.
B. requires the issuer to have a backup line of credit.
C. has a maturity ranging from a few days up to two years.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10236
entry.itemBody: A limit order is an example of a(n):

answerFeedback.10ff9f3f-562d-4200-945a-d69c41316b32: Incorrect because clearing instructions indicate how to arrange the final settlement of the trade.
answerFeedback.1e91217b-fb6d-4d05-908d-80878dfa0fb7: Correct because execution instructions indicate how to fill the order. Market and limit orders convey the most common execution instructions.
answerFeedback.ca772029-32bc-46b8-951c-fb31619bfb54: Incorrect because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08985
entry.itemBody: Direct ownership of commercial real estate most likely:

answerFeedback.3ca6c241-9b69-4fe7-a56c-d037c449dabb: Correct because only the owner can decide when to buy or sell, when and how much to spend on capital projects, whom to select as tenants based on credit quality preference and tenant mix, and what types of lease terms to offer. Owners generate cash flow returns from the use and enjoyment of the property, the receipt of lease payments, and the potential for capital appreciation. REITS are a form of indirect real estate investments, in which investors have less control over underlying properties.
answerFeedback.600585fd-fb1a-4f00-9be7-4590a7d14f0a: Incorrect because  investing directly in property requires significant capital. The owners need to have access to a potentially significant amount of debt and equity capital because of the large initial capital outlay needed for real estate investments. REITS are a form of indirect real estate investments which require lower capital outlay.
answerFeedback.c69dd2e7-61f4-4cf7-b0e0-0385a6c9ac30: Incorrect because it is typically difficult to quickly buy or sell direct investments in real estate, and transaction costs are typically high. REITs and other private real estate funds are structured as infinite-life, open-end funds and allow investors to contribute or redeem capital throughout the life of the fund in a fashion parallel to mutual fund structures.

choices.itemBody: A. provides greater liquidity than a real estate investment trust.
B. requires a lower initial investment than a real estate investment trust.
C. offers greater investor control over underlying properties than a real estate investment trust.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Moustra-07
entry.itemBody: A net investment hedge occurs when a derivative is used to:

answerFeedback.652a04f7-33b8-4448-8c6e-158a81d1c08a: Incorrect because this describes a cash flow hedge, not a net investment hedge. Derivatives designated as absorbing the variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset or liability such as foreign exchange, interest rates, or commodities are referred to as cash flow hedges.
answerFeedback.c7ad0d55-e2d5-4076-869d-02c1e4a443ca: Incorrect because this describes a fair value hedge, not a net investment hedge. A fair value hedge designation applies when a derivative is deemed to offset the fluctuation in fair value of an asset or liability.
answerFeedback.e3e839f9-84ff-4855-90d1-4812860d782a: Correct because net investment hedges occur when either a foreign currency bond or a derivative such as an FX swap or forward is used to offset the exchange rate risk of the equity of a foreign operation.

choices.itemBody: A. offset the fluctuation in the fair value of an asset or liability.
B. absorb the variable cash flow of a floating rate asset or liability.
C. offset the exchange rate risk of the equity of a foreign operation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607070
entry.itemBody: Consider bonds that have the same yield-to-maturity and maturity. The bond with the greatest reinvestment risk is most likely the one selling at:

answerFeedback.278be96d-602f-4381-b38b-6fa2966eeff5: Incorrect because the bond selling at a discount has a lower coupon rate than the bond selling at a premium.
answerFeedback.9a349003-9219-4fe1-8531-5ae21008ec98: Correct because yield-to-maturity is based on the assumption that a bond is held to maturity, does not default, and has its coupon payments reinvested at the yield-to-maturity. The bond selling at a premium has the highest coupon rate and is expected to earn the most reinvestment income from reinvesting those coupon payments at the yield-to-maturity. If the reinvestment rate falls, this bond will suffer the greatest loss.
answerFeedback.c6795acd-07d6-4677-9393-eb4d3f6a9fb4: Incorrect because the bond selling at par has a lower coupon rate than the bond selling at a premium.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02022
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely considered an investor constraint in an investment policy statement?

answerFeedback.001a1c74-f8ab-4d3a-9bca-de0851f7ffd9: Correct because five major types of constraints on portfolio selection are liquidity, time horizon, tax concerns, legal and regulatory factors, and unique circumstances.
answerFeedback.c762087e-c478-4da1-a8ef-e07af1147a77: Incorrect because client's objectives are specified in terms of risk tolerance and return requirements. Risk and return objectives are, therefore, likely to be part of the investment objectives section of the investment policy statement and not part of the constraints section focusing on liquidity, time horizon, tax concerns, legal and regulatory factors, and unique circumstances.
answerFeedback.e2489c4c-7362-40c8-b208-a0c36e302930: Incorrect because client's objectives are specified in terms of risk tolerance and return requirements. Risk and return objectives are, therefore, likely to be part of the investment objectives section of the investment policy statement and not part of the constraints section focusing on liquidity, time horizon, tax concerns, legal and regulatory factors, and unique circumstances.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516068
entry.itemBody: A positive duration gap indicates that a bond investor is currently:

answerFeedback.48df03ec-b2bf-4dba-9fe8-f192d4528a9e: Correct because the duration gap is a bond’s Macaulay duration minus the investment horizon. A positive duration gap indicates that the investor currently is at risk of higher interest rates.
answerFeedback.cdbc539e-1434-41e8-b820-891fa97fc942: Incorrect because a negative (not positive) duration gap indicates that the investor is at risk of lower interest rates.
answerFeedback.e9f275c4-e088-4b47-9189-64ce1522447b: Incorrect because a duration gap of zero (not a positive duration gap) indicates that the bond investor currently is hedged against interest rate risk.

choices.itemBody: A. at risk of lower interest rates.
B. at risk of higher interest rates.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Elkinawy-Young-07
entry.itemBody: Both equity and fixed-income indexes can be categorized according to the:

answerFeedback.13e924a5-be7d-4938-902b-aa9b78101ec9: Incorrect because this feature is specific to fixed-income indexes.
answerFeedback.8fe2687a-e012-4e5b-8bc8-0ab83a80e018: Incorrect because this feature is specific to fixed-income indexes.
answerFeedback.f934539e-cd11-4a69-930a-4307f4747317: Correct because both equity and fixed-income indexes can be constructed according to sector. Similar to equities, fixed-income securities can be categorized according to the issuer’s economic sector, the issuer’s geographic region, or the economic development of the issuer’s geographic region.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-01
entry.itemBody: Real estate is best classified as a:

answerFeedback.088ac9f3-0132-485d-a05d-899e87cd2615: Correct because real assets are tangible properties such as real estate, airplanes, or machinery. Securities, currencies, and contracts are classified as financial assets whereas commodities and real assets (including real estate) are classified as physical assets.
answerFeedback.6367deb2-3695-4730-9e0c-33de68b72e48: Incorrect because commodities include precious metals, energy products, industrial metals, and agricultural products.
answerFeedback.f3bf3aeb-f22e-4e80-a8ac-6140018aaeca: Incorrect because real assets are tangible properties such as real estate, airplanes, or machinery. Securities, currencies, and contracts are classified as financial assets whereas commodities and real assets (including real estate) are classified as physical assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CopyofCFA-L1-04223
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information to evaluate the effect of dividends and leverage on future growth:

  Scenario 1 Scenario 2
Dividend payout ratio 60% 40%
Financial leverage 3.0 2.5

If return on assets is the same for each scenario, the sustainable growth rate is:

answerFeedback.24c8ca50-a565-4b79-b746-1b7d251e312f: Incorrect because scenario 2's sustainable growth rate 1.5 × ROA is higher than Scenario 1's sustainable growth rate 1.2 × ROA.
answerFeedback.bc35eb15-37d4-43c4-ad25-afb3d5e8d17f:
Correct because sustainable growth rate g = b × ROE, where b = retention rate = (1 – Dividend payout ratio), and ROE = ROA × Financial leverage. Thus g = (1 – Dividend payout ratio) × ROA × Financial leverage. Since ROA is unchanged between Scenario 1 and 2:

g scenario 1 = (1 – 0.6) × ROA × 3.0 = 1.2 × ROA; and

g scenario 2 = (1 – 0.4) × ROA × 2.5 = 1.5 × ROA.

Accordingly, scenario 2's sustainable growth rate 1.5 × ROA is higher than Scenario 1's sustainable growth rate 1.2 × ROA.
answerFeedback.d3079ef0-b826-4f21-9214-e5400b77e17e: Incorrect because scenario 2's sustainable growth rate 1.5 × ROA is higher than Scenario 1's sustainable growth rate 1.2 × ROA.

choices.itemBody: C. the same under both Scenario 1 and Scenario 2.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516140
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data (in INR millions) for a company located in India:
Market value of debt 10.0
Market value of preferred stock 5.0
Cash and short-term investments 4.5
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) 15.0

Assuming an enterprise value multiple of 3.2, the company’s market capitalization (in INR millions) is closest to:

answerFeedback.a598f7c4-10e2-493e-9c0e-2f001e08efa1:
Correct because Enterprise value (EV) = EBITDA × EV multiple = 15 × 3.2 = 48.

Market capitalization = EV – Market value (MV) of debt – MV of preferred stock + Cash and short-term investments

= 48 – 10 – 5 + 4.5

= 37.5.
answerFeedback.d433ba42-aebd-4a0d-976b-ec5d39f4ce34:
Incorrect because it incorrectly subtracts cash and short-term investments instead of adding them.

Enterprise Value (EV) = EBITDA × EV multiple = 15 × 3.2 = 48

Market capitalization = Enterprise value – MV of debt – MV of preferred stock – cash and short-term investments

= 48 – 10 – 5 – 4.5 = 28.5
answerFeedback.ecbf9a92-631d-4e2c-b716-91bc7f2c8bf4:
Incorrect. It ignores cash and short-term investments.

Enterprise Value (EV) = EBITDA × EV multiple = 15 × 3.2 = 48

Market capitalization = Enterprise value – MV of debt – MV of preferred stock – cash and short-term investments

= 48 – 10 – 5

= 33

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-02
entry.itemBody: Financial forecasting using historical base rates and convergence is best suited for companies that are:

answerFeedback.2919b528-409f-40aa-bc7c-07ee89754c63: Incorrect because this approach is less appropriate for companies in changing or new industries for which calculating a base rate is difficult or less relevant, for companies in highly cyclical industries for which a longer-term base rate and smooth convergence to it would obscure year-to-year volatility, and for companies that are industry leaders by a wide margin and account for a substantial proportion of any industry base rate.
answerFeedback.5b65330b-81f7-416d-b84e-2df4531d05aa: Incorrect because this approach is less appropriate for companies in changing or new industries for which calculating a base rate is difficult or less relevant, for companies in highly cyclical industries for which a longer-term base rate and smooth convergence to it would obscure year-to-year volatility, and for companies that are industry leaders by a wide margin and account for a substantial proportion of any industry base rate.
answerFeedback.d33dbbc2-1344-48f9-8582-30beda758f7d: Correct because historical base rates and convergence may be appropriate for forecasting companies in well-established industries with many publicly traded peers, such as banks, airlines, restaurants, automakers, and retailers, especially when the analyst’s industry analysis does not call for material changes in industry structure or external industry influences.

choices.itemBody: C. industry leaders by a wide margin.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-30
entry.itemBody: A bond has a modified duration of 7.5 years and an annual convexity of 280. If yields decrease by 60 basis points, the percentage price change is closest to:

answerFeedback.0501fcc4-7fde-4b12-aa4b-84d7887105dd:
Incorrect because the convexity adjustment is subtracted instead of added:

≠ (–7.5 × –0.006) – (0.5 × 280 × 0.0062) 

= 0.045 – 0.00504 = 0.03996 ≈ 4.00%.
answerFeedback.b5c027fd-1255-4041-8167-6fb7c0fdc9f2:
Incorrect because the convexity adjustment is missing the 0.5 in the calculation:

≠ (–7.5 × –0.006) + (280 × 0.0062) 

= 0.045 + 0.01008 = 0.05508 ≈ 5.51%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08468
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the fee structure and performance of a hedge fund with $100 million assets under management at the beginning of the year:

Annual management fee 2%
Incentive fee 20%
Hard hurdle rate 3%

The annual management fee is based on the year-end valuation, and the incentive fee is calculated net of the management fee. If the fund return before fees is 10% at year end, the total annual fee earned by the fund manager is closest to:

answerFeedback.1fcad503-e387-43f4-9895-1cc3626cca72:
Incorrect because a soft hurdle rate is used instead of a hard hurdle rate.

Management fee = $110 million × 2% = $2.2 million.

As the hurdle rate was exceeded, the incentive fee = ($10 million – $2.2 million) × 20% = $1.56 million.

Therefore, total fees = management fee + incentive fee ≠ $2.2 million + $1.56 million = $3.76 million, rounded to $3.8 million.
answerFeedback.87a273cb-8297-4c02-a452-61d8ee032d76:
Correct because the hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. GPs typically receive 20% of the total profit of the private equity fund net of any hard hurdle rate, in which case the GP earns fees on annual returns in excess of the hurdle rate, or net of the soft hurdle rate, in which case the fee is calculated on the entire annual gross return as long as the set hurdle is exceeded.

Management fee = $110 million × 2% = $2.2 million.

Annual return is 10%; and the hard hurdle rate is 3%. Thus the incentive fee is paid on a 7% return: 7% × $100 million = $7 million

Thus the incentive fee = ($7 million – $.2.2 million management fee) × 20% = $0.96 million

Therefore, total fees = management fee + incentive fee = $2.2 million + $0.96 million = $3.16 million, rounded to $3.2 million.
answerFeedback.c8daaacc-676b-45de-a76e-b11a25e3b2e8:
Incorrect because the incentive fee is calculated gross of management fee.

Annual return is 10%; and the hard hurdle rate is 3%. Thus the incentive fee is paid on a 7% return: 7% × $100 million = $7 million.

The incentive fee

≠

$7 million × 20% = $1.4 million.

Therefore, total fees

≠

management fee + incentive fee = $2.2 million + $1.4 million = $3.6 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07386
entry.itemBody: Which of the following measures is least appropriate for evaluating the risk of a currency option?

answerFeedback.b8e513ab-e649-4f9e-87b3-fdf5208112d5: Correct because beta is a measure of the sensitivity of a security's returns to the returns on the market portfolio. Beta measures relative risk, meaning how much market risk an asset contributes to a well-diversified portfolio. Beta describes risk well for a portfolio of equities, but other sources of risk may require other descriptive risk metrics. The risk associated with derivatives is one example of this.
answerFeedback.d5691a2f-e49f-4661-bd2b-25ee51db6cc5: Incorrect because vega is a first-order measure of the change in the derivative price for a change in the volatility of the underlying. Vega is an appropriate measure of derivatives risk, whereas beta is not.
answerFeedback.ef8a4152-0837-403f-9cb8-30969b5e674e: Incorrect because the sensitivity of the derivative price to a small change in the value of the underlying asset is called the delta. It is perhaps the most important measure of derivatives risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-12
entry.itemBody: Compared to a European waterfall, an American waterfall is:

answerFeedback.41e0ee4f-227d-4ec3-bdcb-13a6a0d6701d: Incorrect because deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls are more advantageous to the general partner because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the general partner to get paid before limited partners receive their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund.
answerFeedback.da2c5f64-a3a1-4359-8d1a-00b9d1bb7671: Incorrect because deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls are more advantageous to the general partner because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the general partner to get paid before limited partners receive their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund.
answerFeedback.e70b404d-516a-4954-a147-3b1740fb9155: Correct because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the general partner because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the general partner to get paid before limited partners receive their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund. In whole-of-fund waterfalls, all distributions go to the limited partners as deals are exited and the general partner does not participate in any profits until the limited partners receive their initial investment and the hurdle rate has been met. In contrast to deal-by-deal waterfalls, whole-of-fund waterfalls occur at the aggregate fund level (i.e., after all investments have been exited) and are more advantageous to the limited partners.

choices.itemBody: A. less advantageous to the general partner.
B. equally advantageous to the general partner.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05643
entry.itemBody: For a given equity index, the long-term total return of the index is most likely greater than the price return:

answerFeedback.09765048-969b-4140-8e76-f25c98da897f: Incorrect because as time passes the value of the total return index, which includes the reinvestment of all dividends and/or interest received, will exceed the value of the price return index by an increasing amount.
answerFeedback.281a9e7f-931e-4817-a761-11ef402b5555: Correct because at inception, the values of the price and total return versions of an index are equal. As time passes, however, the value of the total return index, which includes the reinvestment of all dividends and/or interest received, will exceed the value of the price return index by an increasing amount.
answerFeedback.d311752c-8f08-4305-9a70-09d00b4baac4: Incorrect because as time passes the value of the total return index, which includes the reinvestment of all dividends and/or interest received, will exceed the value of the price return index by an increasing amount.

choices.itemBody: B. only when the price returns are less than zero.
C. only when the price returns are equal to or greater than zero.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Tomter-10
entry.itemBody: With respect to a client's IPS, which of the following measures is most likely used when stating a relative risk objective?

answerFeedback.174634a7-465e-462d-86c5-62a3f0b9ff0b: Incorrect because standard deviation of returns is used to measure an absolute risk objective, not a relative risk objective. Measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk.
answerFeedback.c0dbaee8-a767-4742-bb2a-2a4ca9074b69: Correct because quantitative risk objectives can be absolute or relative or a combination of the two. Some clients may choose to express relative risk objectives, which relate risk relative to one or more benchmarks perceived to represent appropriate risk standards. For risk relative to a benchmark, the measure could be tracking risk, or tracking error.
answerFeedback.f07f4173-9bb9-49d7-8de5-8326ac9b20cc: Incorrect because value at risk is used to measure an absolute risk objective, not a relative risk objective. Measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Mazararu-11
entry.itemBody: Hedge funds are most likely characterized by:

answerFeedback.0d6ff4c1-5f38-4843-86be-5cc28f33f525: Correct because hedge fund portfolios approach return generation differently from traditional portfolios. The most significant difference is that hedge funds seek to limit market exposure and returns from beta and primarily focus on generating idiosyncratic returns by identifying sources of unique return, or alpha. Due to this different approach to return generation, hedge fund performance relative to a traditional portfolio may be hard to gauge.
answerFeedback.1027f32f-ab22-4c30-898d-f30d212aa5fe: Incorrect because hedge fund performance has a very low correlation with that of traditional asset classes, such as investment bonds and currencies/cash. (However, hedge funds have a fairly high correlation with equities.)
answerFeedback.1c320547-7e64-420e-862f-e8d3e63ca41b: Incorrect because hedge funds are also subject to much lighter regulatory, compliance, and transparency requirements. With more flexibility in portfolio construction, hedge funds enjoy leeway to invest in situations in which time may be needed to generate an expected return.

choices.itemBody: B. a high correlation of returns with investment-grade bonds.
C. performance relative to a traditional portfolio that may be hard to gauge.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01266
entry.itemBody: Insurance on a portfolio of risky assets is most likely:

answerFeedback.3c0e12c8-52d9-4a3f-ada1-49ff43525ad8: Incorrect because insurance has a negative correlation with other assets in the risky portfolio.
answerFeedback.8195eef9-e084-4fbc-87d0-454d98549a57: Incorrect because insurance has a negative correlation with other assets in the risky portfolio.
answerFeedback.d2f1fcd0-9740-4060-8b35-327c7a87a136: Correct because insurance has a negative correlation with other assets and is, thus, very valuable. Insurance gives a positive return when other assets lose value, but pays nothing if other assets maintain their value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09004
entry.itemBody: When forming asset classes for a strategic asset allocation, the defined asset classes should:

answerFeedback.3e808b42-1026-40f8-a61a-e011d2ed8d58: Incorrect because paired correlations of assets should be relatively high (not negative) within an asset class.
answerFeedback.60e799ae-53c7-42c7-b666-24b47875642c: Correct because asset classes, while being mutually exclusive, should add up to a sufficient approximation of the relevant investable universe.
answerFeedback.a2452619-3b9b-47d2-8c07-7fdf7ca8622d: Incorrect because an asset class should provide diversification relative to other asset classes. In statistical terms paired correlations of assets should be lower versus assets in other asset classes.

choices.itemBody: B. have high pairwise correlations between them.
C. contain negatively correlated assets within each asset class.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09320
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's common stock:

Dividend per share – Year 1 $2.00
Dividend per share – Year 2 $2.10
Annual dividend per share – Year 3 and beyond $2.21

If the required rate of return is 10%, the intrinsic value per share is closest to:

answerFeedback.316ed783-3bc9-4f72-a01f-c557894a21b1: Incorrect because it is only the present value of the perpetual level dividends three years from now. $2.21 / (0.10 – 0) = $22.10.
answerFeedback.5bafbadc-def4-4fb5-bb8c-35972aa12c12: Correct because it is the present value of all future dividends. The present value of the perpetual level dividends, three years from now, is: $2.21 / (0.10 – 0) = $22.10. The present value of the perpetual level dividends now is: $22.10 / (1.10)3 = $16.604. The present of dividends in the first three years is: $2.00 / 1.10 + $2.10 / (1.10)2 + $2.21 / (1.10)3 = $1.818 + $1.736 + $1.660 = $5.214. So, the intrinsic value of the stock is closest to: $16.604 + $5.214 = $21.818 ≈ $21.82.
answerFeedback.f2ad8bed-4f74-4681-9470-0b10496aa003: Incorrect because the present value of the level dividends in perpetuity three years from now has been added to the present value of the dividends in Year 1, Year 2 and Year 3, without discounting it for three years (see calculations in correct answer). $22.100 + $5.214 = $27.314 ≈ $27.31.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Ebeling-04
entry.itemBody: A call option with an exercise price of $38 was bought for $3. The price of the underlying increases from $42 to $47. At expiration, the payoff to the call buyer is equal to:

answerFeedback.1f132838-8a8f-4ca2-aebe-960259774935: Incorrect because this is the profit to the call buyer calculated Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0 (profit to the call buyer) and inputting the values ST = $47 as the price of the underlying at expiration less $38 = X as the exercise price, and then subtracting the call premium of $3 yields $6.
answerFeedback.3dbd06b6-2514-4f2f-9be8-cb3b30a6211e: Correct because cT = Max(0,ST – X) (payoff to the call buyer) and inputting the values ST = $47 as the price of the underlying at expiration less $38 = X as the exercise price yields $9.
answerFeedback.cae7f1f2-bec8-4748-b214-ddc623d66052: Incorrect because the correct formula cT = Max(0,ST – X) (payoff to the call buyer) is changed to deduct 38 = X the exercise price from the current price of the underlying S0 = $42 (instead of the price at expiration $47) to yield $4.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08847
entry.itemBody: According to capital market theory, the only type of risk that is priced is:

answerFeedback.63c520cb-2da1-4579-8fc5-68e82efeb5b7: Correct because systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk. Pricing or valuing an asset is equivalent to estimating its expected rate of return.
answerFeedback.dc302197-21cc-45ef-8e77-ed0d1b58d1e9: Incorrect because systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk.
answerFeedback.fedaad1f-4a03-4c63-b8db-6009c4932a40: Incorrect because systematic or non-diversifiable risk is priced and investors are compensated for holding assets or portfolios based only on that investment's systematic risk. Investors do not receive any return for accepting nonsystematic or diversifiable risk. Nonsystematic risk is the risk that pertains to a single company or industry and is also known as company-specific, industry-specific, diversifiable, or idiosyncratic risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09658
entry.itemBody: An increase in which of the following most likely increases the time value of a European put option?

answerFeedback.8d883496-8a16-4aac-adf6-080c0040afcc: Incorrect because the value of a European put is inversely (not directly) related to the risk-free interest rate.
answerFeedback.a9043f0a-2b58-4f26-9a6f-b559bb094939: Correct because the time value reflects the value of the uncertainty that arises from the volatility in the underlying. Also, time value results in an option price being greater with volatility and time but declining as expiration approaches. Therefore, the increase in the volatility of the underlying will increase the time value of a put option. In contrast, the value of a European put is inversely related to the risk-free interest rate.
answerFeedback.af624be0-7d0f-408a-a862-a7f15362a413: Incorrect because the value of a European put is inversely (not directly) related to the risk-free interest rate.

choices.itemBody: C. Both the volatility of the underlying and the current market interest rate

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Deriv 04DPQ
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information:

Risk-free rate per annum 1.50%
Exercise price $9.75
9-month call option price $3.25

According to put–call–forward parity, the price of a 9-month fiduciary call is closest to:

answerFeedback.00f3d379-05fe-417c-8beb-544c65117c65: Correct because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic protective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity: F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T where c0 is the price of the European call, p0 is the price of the European Put, F0 is the forward price of the underlying, X is the exercise price, r is the risk-free rate and T is time. Therefore the price of a 9-month fiduciary call is equal to the price of a 9-month synthetic protective put and can be calculated by c0 + X/(1 + r)T = $3.25 + $9.75/(1 + 0.015)9/12 = $3.25 + $9.64 = $12.89.
answerFeedback.9ef75d8a-7749-431c-a941-ded28e547744: Incorrect because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic protective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity: F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T where c0 is the price of the European call, p0 is the price of the European Put, F0 is the forward price of the underlying, X is the exercise price, r is the risk-free rate and T is time. Therefore the price of a 9-month fiduciary call is not equal to c0 + X × (1 + r)T or $3.25 + $9.75 × (1 + 0.015)9/12 = $3.25 + $9.86 = $13.11
answerFeedback.e973eb89-7045-46f9-8040-b01feb40bc90: Incorrect because the cost of the fiduciary call must equal the cost of the synthetic protective put, giving us what is referred to as put–call–forward parity: F0(T)/(1 + r)T + p0 = c0 + X/(1 + r)T where c0 is the price of the European call, p0 is the price of the European Put, F0 is the forward price of the underlying, X is the exercise price, r is the risk-free rate and T is time. Therefore the price of a 9-month fiduciary call is not equal to c0 + X or $3.25 + $9.75 = $13.00.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Deriv 03HFJ
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a European call option with 9 months until expiration:

Current stock price $112
Strike price of option $115
Current call option price $4
1-year risk free rate 2.5%

According to put–call parity, the current price of a put option with the same maturity and strike price is closest to:

answerFeedback.2460c1ab-e242-4429-9551-275c6ab54fc9: Correct because the current value of the put option is $4.89, according to put-call parity formula: p0 – c0 = X / (1 + r)T – S0, where p0 is the put price, c0 is the call price, X is the strike price, r is the risk free rate with T time to expiration and S0, is the current stock price. p0 = $115 / (1 + 0.025)0.75 – $112 + $4 = $4.89.
answerFeedback.4d48c5d9-abc4-41ad-8d85-a8dbe4cd764d: Incorrect because the current value of the put option is $4.89, according to put-call parity formula: p0 – c0 = X / (1 + r)T – S0, where p0 is the put price, c0 is the call price, X is the strike price, r is the risk free rate with T time to expiration and S0, is the current stock price. p0 = $115 / (1 + 0.025)0.75 – $112 + $4 = $4.89. Switching p0 with c0 in the formula and solving for c0 will result in the wrong answer $3.11 as c0 = p0 --X / (1 + r)T +S0 or c0 = $4 -$115 / (1 + 0.025)0.75 + $112 = $3.11
answerFeedback.5adf2798-e56f-413e-9673-be4fe15da327: Incorrect because the current value of the put option is $4.89, according to put-call parity formula: p0 – c0 = X / (1 + r)T – S0, where p0 is the put price, c0 is the call price, X is the strike price, r is the risk free rate with T time to expiration and S0, is the current stock price. p0 = $115 / (1 + 0.025)0.75 – $112 + $4 = $4.89. Assuming T = 1 will result in the wrong answer $4.20 as $115 / (1 + 0.025)1 – $112 + $4 = $4.20.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07182
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about spot rates:

Time Period Spot Rate
1 year 2%
2 year 3%
3 year 4%

Using spot rates, the price of a 3-year, 6% annual coupon bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.2ee50414-9cda-4792-adc2-6e4f26241f6d:
Incorrect because it incorrectly uses the 3-year spot rate in the denominator of each component of the calculation:

PV = 6/ (1 + 0.04)1 + 6 / (1 + 0.04)2 + (6 + 100) / (1 + 0.04)3 = 105.55.
answerFeedback.4e50d1b3-8558-4d62-a033-784a322c6545:
Incorrect because it incorrectly uses “3” as the exponent in the denominator of each component of the calculation:

PV = 6/ (1 + 0.02)3 + 6 / (1 + 0.03)3 + (6 + 100) / (1 + 0.04)3 = 105.38.
answerFeedback.5c8732b8-23e9-42bf-a4a7-957241a502dd:
Correct because the general formula for calculating a bond price given the sequence

of spot rates: PV = PMT / (1 + Z1)1 + PMT / (1 + Z2)2 + … + (PMT + FV) / (1 + ZN)N

Where

PV = present value, or the price of the bond

PMT = coupon payment per period

FV = future value paid at maturity, or the par value of the bond

Z1 = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 1

Z2 = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period 2

ZN = spot rate, or the zero-coupon yield, or zero rate, for Period N:

PV = 6/ (1 + 0.02)1 + 6 / (1 + 0.03)2 + (6 + 100) / (1 + 0.04)3 = 105.77.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-28
entry.itemBody: If yields decrease by 0.75%, the convexity adjustment for a bond with an annual convexity of 400 is:

answerFeedback.51dffe98-fa3b-407a-833f-d43c4daf19ec:
Incorrect because the 0.5 is missing in the formula:

Convexity adjustment ≠ (400 × 0.00752) = 0.02250
answerFeedback.89f26d12-3ed5-4d14-ba5b-d18187e99dae:
Correct because the “second order” effect, is the convexity adjustment. The convexity adjustment is the annual convexity statistic, AnnConvexity, times one-half, multiplied by the change in the yield-to-maturity squared.

Convexity adjustment = (0.5 × AnnConvexity × ΔYield2)

= (0.5 × 400 × 0.00752) = 0.01125.
answerFeedback.c70e7de9-344a-46b6-8985-15de7b619f72:
Incorrect because the change in yield is not squared:

Convexity adjustment ≠ (0.5 × 400 × 0.0075) = 1.50000.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00691
entry.itemBody: Compared to a defined benefit plan's investment time horizon, a bank's investment time horizon is most likely:

answerFeedback.0472ee47-ab4d-49b9-9959-8a59442986fb: Incorrect because banks typically have much shorter investment time horizons than defined benefit plans.
answerFeedback.b0816721-06e1-4f31-8adc-f7a4db0e6d91: Correct because the defined benefit plan may have an indefinitely long time horizon if new plan members are being admitted. As for banks, the time horizon is short term.
answerFeedback.b0d0f734-c8a8-4f43-b051-6243a409ea84: Incorrect because banks typically have much shorter investment time horizons than defined benefit plans.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Fairborn-07
entry.itemBody: Management fees for private equity funds are most likely based on:

answerFeedback.30ae451d-6ca7-494d-a017-14c07ccf2234: Incorrect because private equity funds raise committed capital and draw down on those commitments, generally over three to five years, when they have a specific investment to make. Note that the management fee is typically based on committed capital, not invested capital; the committed-capital basis for management fees is an important distinction from hedge funds, whose management fees are based on assets under management (AUM).
answerFeedback.698b8b4b-d93d-4aaf-8937-faf9cd66b0a2: Correct because private equity funds raise committed capital and draw down on those commitments, generally over three to five years, when they have a specific investment to make. Note that the management fee is typically based on committed capital, not invested capital; the committed-capital basis for management fees is an important distinction from hedge funds, whose management fees are based on assets under management (AUM).
answerFeedback.97e1b2eb-2590-4f82-a2dd-2deaa514ee49: Incorrect because private equity funds raise committed capital and draw down on those commitments, generally over three to five years, when they have a specific investment to make. Note that the management fee is typically based on committed capital, not invested capital; the committed-capital basis for management fees is an important distinction from hedge funds, whose management fees are based on assets under management (AUM).

entry.title: ITEM_20170516049
entry.itemBody: A portfolio manager analyzes a market and discovers that it is not possible to achieve consistent and superior risk-adjusted returns, net of all expenses. This market is most likely characterized by:

answerFeedback.2f74d591-b29c-4811-b5bd-12521ff96bd9: Incorrect because in an informationally efficient market, consistent and superior risk-adjusted returns (net of all expenses) are not achievable. In such a situation, persistent anomalies are unlikely.
answerFeedback.62b18734-30d8-4982-b927-182f0787372a: Incorrect because some market experts argue that restrictions on short selling limit arbitrage trading, which impedes market efficiency.
answerFeedback.7ef00d1b-e038-42c1-a982-fcaa16b76155: Correct because in an informationally efficient market, consistent and superior risk-adjusted returns (net of all expenses) are not achievable.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Berlinicke-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about the use of derivative instruments is most accurate?

answerFeedback.abd9d29e-51f5-4aca-a33e-f1bfddf0a1b9: Incorrect because the opposite is true: Derivatives typically have lower (not higher) transaction costs and are often more liquid than underlying spot market transactions.
answerFeedback.ccfb11fd-4446-44e3-a1aa-872e4d74da47: Incorrect because the opposite is true: Market participants may create large (not small) exposures to an underlying with a relatively small cash outlay.
answerFeedback.feb64399-d654-4728-b2ff-8ff21215561e: Correct because derivative markets expand the set of opportunities available to market participants to create or modify exposure to an underlying in several ways, including allowing Issuers to offset the financial market exposure associated with a commercial transaction.

choices.itemBody: A. Small exposures to an underlying can be created with a large cash outlay
B. Financial market exposure associated with commercial transactions can be offset by issuers
C. Higher transaction costs are typically incurred compared to underlying spot market transactions

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following cognitive errors is best classified as a belief perseverance bias?

answerFeedback.43f0cc67-29e5-4580-8b2b-b196ca9579f1: Incorrect because it is a processing error, not a belief perseverance bias. The processing errors discussed are anchoring and adjustment, mental accounting, framing, and availability.
answerFeedback.4eca1e8f-8060-4412-b48b-b80a5bf0bf2c: Correct because the belief perseverance biases discussed are conservatism, confirmation, representativeness, illusion of control, and hindsight. Confirmation bias refers to the tendency to look for and notice what confirms prior beliefs and to ignore or undervalue whatever contradicts them.
answerFeedback.6f5de59b-307d-4b62-ae8c-a4bf8fed1353: Incorrect because it is a processing error, not a belief perseverance bias. The processing errors discussed are anchoring and adjustment, mental accounting, framing, and availability.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05330
entry.itemBody: The redemption value of a US Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) issue at maturity is most likely:

answerFeedback.819ab7f6-abe3-4f37-b151-16fac824eeca: Incorrect because investors can never receive below par. TIPS, which have a periodic principal adjustment based on a price index, are an example of a capital-indexed bond. Note that while deflation causes the principal to decline over time, investors usually receive the greater of the inflation-adjusted principal or par at maturity.
answerFeedback.942efa43-47a8-4937-bac3-5fb2cecd91a9: Correct because TIPS, which have a periodic principal adjustment based on a price index, are an example of a capital-indexed bond. Note that while deflation causes the principal to decline over time, investors usually receive the greater of the inflation-adjusted principal or par at maturity.
answerFeedback.df72e647-0e94-4e5e-9798-9fb5675d4075: Incorrect because investors receive the greater of inflation-adjusted or par at maturity. TIPS, which have a periodic principal adjustment based on a price index, are an example of a capital-indexed bond. Note that while deflation causes the principal to decline over time, investors usually receive the greater of the inflation-adjusted principal or par at maturity.

choices.itemBody: B. the greater of the inflation-adjusted principal or initial par value.
C. above or below the initial par value depending on actual inflation during the term.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 04EJT
entry.itemBody: Tactical asset allocation is best described as adding value by:

answerFeedback.5c316757-9abd-4a89-b53b-f2a0465ed208: Incorrect because it describes strategic asset allocation, not tactical asset allocation. A strategic asset allocation results from combining the constraints and objectives articulated in the IPS and long-term capital market expectations regarding the asset classes.
answerFeedback.abb6a672-0ca9-4f1e-968b-c2e09100ffbc: Incorrect because it describes risk budgeting, not tactical asset allocation. Risk budgeting is the process of deciding on the amount of risk to assume in a portfolio (the overall risk budget), and subdividing that risk over the sources of investment return (e.g., strategic asset allocation, tactical asset allocation, and security selection).
answerFeedback.c54aa7ad-7d82-457e-a26a-a1c8285a9d5c: Correct because tactical asset allocation is the decision to deliberately deviate from the policy exposures to systematic risk factors (i.e., the policy weights of asset classes) with the intent to add value based on forecasts of the near-term returns of those asset classes.

choices.itemBody: A. subdividing portfolio risk over the sources of investment return.
B. deliberately deviating from policy exposures to systematic risk factors.
C. combining long-term capital market expectations with investor objectives and constraints.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Bangaruswamy-18
entry.itemBody: In a one-period binomial model, the risk-neutral probabilities of upward and downward price movements of an underlying asset are determined by:

answerFeedback.7a67308d-dae3-465f-824e-ad25853ea126: Incorrect because of the ability to construct a perfect hedge of the option using the underlying asset, an option’s price is independent of investors’ risk aversion and the probability of the underlying price moving up (or down).
answerFeedback.c0d99343-e002-4af4-bec0-834ec8ece175: Correct because in a one-period binomial model, the risk-neutral probabilities are determined only by the risk-free rate over the life of the option and the underlying asset’s volatility (as measured by the up and down gross returns, Ru and Rd).
answerFeedback.fb7709ae-dcb1-4ba4-821a-57f73a6807a4: Incorrect because of the ability to construct a perfect hedge of the option using the underlying asset, an option’s price is independent of investors’ risk aversion and the probability of the underlying price moving up (or down).

choices.itemBody: C. the probabilities of the underlying price moving up and down.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04810
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a call for $24.70 that has a strike price of $650. If the value at expiration for this call is $47.60, the price of the underlying at expiration is closest to:

answerFeedback.31022d9e-15a7-4bce-86d9-80067221b976: Correct because the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X) where X is the strike price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $47.60 = Max(0,ST – $650). Hence, ST =$ 650 + $47.60 = $697.60.
answerFeedback.4292998d-ea4c-4e4e-9bf8-2fda44f75f01: Incorrect because $602.40 represents the value or "payoff to the put buyer" at expiration, which is pT = Max(0, X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $47.60 = Max(0,$650 – ST) which yields ST = $650 – $47.60 = $602.40. By contrast, the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X). Given the information in the stem we get $47.60 = Max(0,ST – $650). Hence, ST = 650 + 47.60 = 697.60, not $602.40.
answerFeedback.4656c5f5-fdcb-474a-b08c-49e5d7ad2e32: Incorrect because $672.90 simply represents the difference between $697.60 and $24.70. By contrast, the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X) where X is the strike price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $47.60 = Max(0,ST – $650). Hence, ST =$ 650 + $47.60 = $697.60, not $672.90.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01046
entry.itemBody: An annual-pay bond with a £1,000 face value has a coupon rate of 4% and matures in three years. If the yield to maturity is 3%, the current value of the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.766912a6-e00a-4497-adfa-6f33010a21aa:
Incorrect because it changes the discount rate and time period to semiannual and leaves the payment as annual.

FV = £1,000

I = 1.5

N = 6

PMT = 40

PV = £1,142
answerFeedback.a77c268a-48ba-4616-8b9a-428b74a387fa:
Incorrect because it changes the payment amount to semiannual but leaves the time period and discount rate as annual.

FV = £1,000

I = 3

N = 3

PMT = 20

PV = £972 rounded

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09862
entry.itemBody: With respect to the absolute priority of claims in bankruptcy, which of the following most likely has the highest seniority ranking?

answerFeedback.7aa32ad6-1364-4968-8324-849a3fc9da7d: Incorrect because as specified in the justification for the correct response, senior unsecured debt ranks below third lien debt (secured debt).
answerFeedback.9a7fc785-7168-42b5-a73e-853a5ab2e3b1: Correct because in the event of default, unsecured debtholders' claims rank below (i.e., get paid after) those of secured creditors under what's known as the priority of claims. Within secured debt there can also be second lien, or even third lien, secured debt, which, as the name implies, has a secured interest in the pledged assets but ranks below first lien debt in both collateral protection and priority of payment. Other, lower-ranked debt includes subordinated debt and junior subordinated debt.
answerFeedback.e721bf2d-a900-4812-9e74-d7bf25a078fa: Incorrect because as specified in the justification for the correct response, subordinated debt ranks below third lien debt (secured debt).

entry.title: ITEM_20170516038
entry.itemBody: Compared with its market-value-weighted counterpart, a fundamental-weighted index is least likely to have a:

answerFeedback.2bec81b5-12c2-4dc4-b84a-e3e23c595796: Correct because the momentum effect is a characteristic of a market-capitalization-weighted index, not a fundamental index.
answerFeedback.54ce0842-9780-44c3-82c5-c7274dd4f957: Incorrect because the fundamental indexes generally have a contrarian effect in that the portfolio weights will shift away from securities that have increased in relative value whenever the portfolio is rebalanced.
answerFeedback.977c5fda-8311-4cef-88fc-2e30da868e65: Incorrect because fundamental weighting leads to a value tilt because the ratios of book value, earnings, dividends, etc., to market value of the firms in a fundamental index tend to be larger than those of the firms in its market-capitalization-weighted counterpart.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-04
entry.itemBody: In contrast to risk tolerance, risk budgeting focuses more on:

answerFeedback.64fbcbf0-ea2a-4196-aa17-e3ebd7afc2b0: Correct because whereas risk tolerance focuses on the appetite for risk and what is and is not acceptable, risk budgeting has a more specific focus on how that risk is taken.
answerFeedback.9382585c-8e63-4834-89a5-64dc9b18d1f1: Incorrect because whereas risk tolerance focuses on the appetite for risk and what is and is not acceptable, risk budgeting has a more specific focus on how that risk is taken.
answerFeedback.9dcf9202-e054-4900-9447-9ba7ff27f4db: Incorrect because whereas risk tolerance focuses on the appetite for risk and what is and is not acceptable, risk budgeting has a more specific focus on how that risk is taken.

choices.itemBody: C. what is and is not acceptable risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10952
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? Cryptocurrencies:

answerFeedback.592fae6d-b981-47b9-90cf-fe560f64a3f1: Incorrect because many cryptocurrencies have a self-imposed limit on the total amount of currency they may issue.
answerFeedback.650cb3dc-1311-4902-a320-b79777c74c14: Incorrect because it is important to note that many cryptocurrencies have experienced high levels of price volatility. A lack of clear fundamentals underlying these currencies has contributed to their volatility.
answerFeedback.9970e935-8df1-4e53-9496-a46d6d0fc1a2: Correct because a cryptocurrency, also known as a digital currency, operates as electronic currency and allows near-real-time transactions between parties without the need for an intermediary, such as a bank.

choices.itemBody: B. have no limits on the total amount of currency that may be issued.
C. allow transactions between parties without the need for an intermediary.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Baillie-02
entry.itemBody: The duration statistic that best measures the interest rate risk of a bond that does not have a well-defined internal rate of return is:

answerFeedback.aef2492d-9768-4520-b2c7-a1922f8bd79b: Incorrect because effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.c074a8e7-6080-4ec3-8fc8-1a4ba6ead0a6: Incorrect because effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.d2216b77-dad4-4af8-b40b-5c5835312053: Correct because effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Georgiou-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three well-diversified equity portfolios:

Portfolio Mean return Beta
1   9.2% 1.2
2 12.4% 1.4
3 15.0% 2.3

Given a risk-free rate of 1.8%, the portfolio with the highest Treynor ratio is:

answerFeedback.34cb0f66-ee0a-408c-a030-19dd1e03d124:
Incorrect because Portfolio 3 has the lowest Treynor ratio of the three portfolios.

TR3 = (R3 − Rf ) / β3

= (15.0% − 1.8%) / 2.3

= 0.0574
answerFeedback.93809111-0922-479e-88af-50de3cefbe8b:
Incorrect because the Treynor ratio of Portfolio 1 ranks above Portfolio 3, but below Portfolio 2.

TR1 = (R1 − Rf ) / β1

= (9.2% − 1.8%) / 1.2

= 0.0617
answerFeedback.c16fe97a-b216-4471-b368-79dd96439629:
Correct because the Treynor Ratio of Portfolio 2 is the highest of the three portfolios.

TR2 = (R2 − Rf ) / β2

= (12.4% − 1.8%) / 1.4

= 0.0757

Portfolio Calculation Treynor Ratio
1 (9.2% − 1.8%) / 1.2

0.0617
2 (12.4% − 1.8%) / 1.4 0.0757
3 (15.0% − 1.8%) / 2.3 0.0574

The Treynor ratio is a simple extension of the Sharpe ratio and resolves the Sharpe ratio’s first limitation by substituting beta (systematic risk) for total risk. The portfolio with the highest Treynor ratio will be the best performing based on that measure.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04725
entry.itemBody: The modified duration of an option-free corporate bond best estimates the percentage price change due to changes in the:

answerFeedback.017e20ce-b2a7-4c52-af0c-45b1f4ce6ddb: Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond's own yield-to-maturity whereas, effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond's price to a change in a benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.1596a241-7512-4434-984d-8927847385a0: Incorrect because a horizon yield is the internal rate of return between the total return (the sum of reinvested coupon payments and the sale price or redemption amount) and the purchase price of the bond. The horizon yield on a bond investment is the annualized holding-period rate of return. The horizon yield is a historical measure of yield for an investor's holding period, and not an estimate of future bond price changes.
answerFeedback.2f13a902-caeb-46dd-bed7-4a5138ae0f4b: Correct because modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606073
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio:

  Portfolio Weight Standard Deviation
Asset 1 25% 12%
Asset 2 75% 16%

If the correlation coefficient between the two assets is 0.75, the standard deviation of the portfolio is closest to:

answerFeedback.643bccd0-1ba2-456d-9a81-d715fb4f8240:
Correct because the formula for calculating the standard deviation of a two stock portfolio, σp, is:

σp = [w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2ρ12σ1σ2]1/2

where:

w = weight of each stock

σ = standard deviation

ρ12 = the correlation of returns between Stock 1 and Stock 2

Plugging in the numbers, σp =

[(0.252 × 0.122) + (0.752 × 0.162) + (2 × 0.25 × 0.75 × 0.12 × 0.16 × 0.75)]0.5 ≈ 0.1439 = 14.39%
answerFeedback.7a32802a-e017-42ec-b458-d636639a4b2d: Incorrect because it omits the correlation coefficient in calculating the standard deviation: [(0.252 × 0.122) + (0.752 × 0.162) + (2 × 0.25 × 0.75 × 0.12 × 0.16)]0.5 = 0.15 = 15%, which is the weighted average standard deviation.
answerFeedback.b93165ad-5411-460a-8a5b-70a481c2b131: Incorrect because it omits the third term in the formula in calculating the standard deviation: [(0.252 × 0.122) + (0.752 × 0.162)]0.5 ≈ 0.1237 = 12.37%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606086
entry.itemBody: Two investors have utility functions that differ only with regard to the coefficient of risk aversion. Relative to the investor with a higher coefficient of risk aversion, the optimal portfolio for the investor with a lower coefficient of risk aversion will most likely have:

answerFeedback.4e98cfcf-d5af-421d-9af4-e7285a457078: Incorrect. Only investors with identical coefficients of risk aversion would select the same optimal portfolio.
answerFeedback.b371e695-2312-4af7-b811-5a52a4595ff3: Correct. A less risk-averse investor’s highest utility curve, given the lower coefficient of risk aversion, is likely to touch the capital allocation line at a point that would represent a portfolio with higher risk and more expected return.
answerFeedback.b8adc37c-9ec3-4d4d-a624-5c8f080086ea: Incorrect. For a high coefficient of risk aversion, the investor will seek a lot of return for a bit of extra risk and will have an optimal portfolio that is tangential to the capital allocation line at a lower level of risk and return relative to the investor with a lower coefficient of risk aversion.

choices.itemBody: A. a lower level of risk and return.
B. the same level of risk and return.
C. a higher level of risk and return.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Augulyte-13
entry.itemBody: Which of the following involves a private equity firm introducing leverage to its portfolio company and paying itself a dividend out of the new capital structure?

answerFeedback.29fb7238-72ee-4eeb-8638-28c380984fd5: Correct because recapitalization via private equity describes the steps a firm takes to increase or introduce leverage to its portfolio company and pay itself a dividend out of the new capital structure.
answerFeedback.49afafe9-01cb-4078-affe-d08a66a39827: Incorrect because it's one of the primary methods. We can organize the primary methods of private debt investing into four categories: direct lending, mezzanine loans, venture debt, and distressed debt.
answerFeedback.583a4843-a855-43b6-a0d4-400a52be6e9e: Incorrect because it's one of the primary methods. We can organize the primary methods of private debt investing into four categories: direct lending, mezzanine loans, venture debt, and distressed debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Agarwal-01
entry.itemBody: A European call option has an exercise price of $80 and an option premium of $12. The price of the underlying is $75. The intrinsic value of the option is:

answerFeedback.4c5a093d-8d2e-4c03-95da-9edc2f9fe78e: Incorrect because this is the time value if it were a put option and not the intrinsic value of a call option. The time value of an option is the difference between the market price of the option and its intrinsic value. Time value of the put option = Market price –Intrinsic value = $12 – Max(0,$80 – $75) = $7.
answerFeedback.60131e3e-64ea-452a-b81b-8f9f829f911c: Incorrect because this would be the intrinsic value if it were a put option. The value of a European put at expiration is the exercise value, which is the greater of zero or the exercise price minus the value of the underlying. Intrinsic value of the hypothetical put option = Max(0,$80 – $75) = $5.
answerFeedback.69505705-b460-4d05-8f8b-2dca50971538: Correct because the value of the option at expiration is the greater of either zero or the underlying price at expiration minus the exercise price, which is typically written as CT = Max(0,ST – X) This formula is also sometimes referred to as the exercise value or intrinsic value. Intrinsic value of call option = Max(0,$75 – $80) = $0.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Alt 05SXL
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely provides the greatest redemption flexibility?

answerFeedback.315ffeea-25c1-48dd-be27-f22d42c75c1c: Incorrect because private equity investments generally involve an initial capital commitment, but actual capital ﬂows often lag that commitment because capital “calls” are staggered over substantive periods of time. Private equity returns are frequently described in terms of the J-curve eﬀect: a substantive initial capital commitment promise, followed by high initial fee drag, followed by the identification of longer-term growth or turnaround opportunities, and an eventual positive return (the investor hopes) when the staggered returns of the fund are realized. The component investments mature and are sold at various times, and the partnership finally closes—but usually only after six to eight years (often with two-year extensions allowed at the discretion of the general partner or after a vote of approval by a majority of limited partners). Therefore, a private equity fund does not offer the greatest redemption flexibility to an investor.
answerFeedback.7b76feb3-5f62-48cf-bcff-1280f94aca93: Incorrect because alternative investments often have restrictions on redemptions (i.e., “lockups” and “gates”). Investors may be required to keep their money in the hedge fund for a minimum period (referred to as a lockup period) before they are allowed to make withdrawals or redeem shares. Furthermore, investors may be required to give notice of their intent to redeem; the notice period is typically 30–90 days. Therefore, a hedge fund does not offer the greatest redemption flexibility to an investor.
answerFeedback.b750dfda-780e-49aa-a22d-3a3b1fe9317a: Correct because funds of hedge funds may oﬀer more redemption ﬂexibility than is aﬀorded to direct investors in hedge funds because of special redemption arrangements with the underlying hedge fund managers, the maintenance of added cash reserves, access to temporary bridge-loan financing, or the simple avoidance of less liquid hedge fund strategies.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516138
entry.itemBody: An equity portfolio manager is evaluating her sector allocation strategy for the upcoming year. She expects the global economy to experience a slowdown period for the next two years. Furthermore, she believes that companies will be facing diminishing growth rates with respect to revenues and profits. On the basis of these beliefs, the portfolio manager will most likely overweight:

answerFeedback.2777ade3-3619-41fc-8c44-cf70a6348210: Incorrect because the telecommunication sector exhibits less economic sensitivity, so it should be overweighted, not underweighted.
answerFeedback.eb73c4c0-16e7-4b6f-a8f7-7ec803f2a9a0: Correct because in periods of economic slowdowns, the manager would tend to overweight in non-cyclical companies, such as consumer staples.
answerFeedback.fb9a9ed8-2229-4af1-81f5-a50b96cf4882: Incorrect because the materials sector tends to exhibit a relatively high degree of economic sensitivity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09323
entry.itemBody: A company's depository receipts most likely trade:

answerFeedback.98785701-975d-4a2f-91bd-f1fd88b8d90f: Incorrect because depository receipts represent the equity of international companies and are traded on local exchanges and in the local currencies. With these securities, investors have to worry less about currency conversions (price quotations and dividend payments are in the investor's local currency), unfamiliar market practices, and differences in accounting standards.
answerFeedback.df81737d-25ea-4974-a6dd-e639b8a60b26: Correct because a depository receipt (DR) is a security that trades like an ordinary share on an investor's local exchange and represents an economic interest in a foreign company. It allows the publicly listed shares of a foreign company to be traded on an exchange outside its domestic market.
answerFeedback.e7ae9a83-a33b-42d6-8717-79d662b5c086: Incorrect because a depository receipt (DR) is a security that trades like an ordinary share on an investor's local exchange and represents an economic interest in a foreign company. It allows the publicly listed shares of a foreign company to be traded on an exchange outside its domestic market. It trades in investors', not the company's, local currency.

choices.itemBody: A. like ordinary shares on the investors' local exchanges.
B. in the local currency on the company's local exchange.
C. in the company's currency on investors' local exchanges.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516117
entry.itemBody: An investor opens a margin account with an initial deposit of $5,000. He then purchases 300 shares of a stock at $30 per share using margin. The account requires a maintenance margin of 30%. Ignoring commissions and interest, the price below which the investor will first receive a margin call is closest to:

answerFeedback.08752996-859b-42bc-ae72-e8fd31aa7ad5:
Incorrect because this answer is derived by subtracting the equity instead of the margin loan in the numerator.

( P×300 )−5,000 P×300 =30%

P = $23.81
answerFeedback.d748320e-e18a-4e02-95cb-2fab017ab8bd:
Incorrect because this answer is derived by using the total purchase price of the stock instead of the margin loan.

( P×300 )−( 30×300 ) P×300 =30%

P = $23.08
answerFeedback.daa84724-b6b1-4173-92b2-a86664597e5a:
Correct because the price below which the investor will receive a margin call can be calculated using the equation for calculating maintenance margin.

Maintenance margin = Equity ÷ Market value =

5,000+( P×300 )−( 30×300 ) P×300 =30%

Solving for Price, P = $19.05

entry.title: ITEM_20170601040
entry.itemBody: What is the most likely reason why arbitrage will not completely eliminate all pricing discrepancies for derivatives?

answerFeedback.038358f2-4575-4c45-9097-04ee166dff32: Incorrect. No forecasts are needed in implementing an arbitrage position.
answerFeedback.378360ea-28da-4b24-8779-d37d8b894a21: Incorrect. Differences in risk aversion are irrelevant for arbitrage because arbitrage transactions are riskless.
answerFeedback.a226ae79-4657-46da-b3b4-5260d90b935c: Correct. Transaction costs may render an arbitrage strategy unprofitable and can therefore prevent precise convergence of prices.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Moustra-03
entry.itemBody: Key rate duration measures the sensitivity of a bond's price to a change in:

answerFeedback.11470476-ed6e-480c-9929-bfe9bb1e652e: Correct because a key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve at a specific maturity segment. In contrast to effective duration, key rate durations help identify “shaping risk” for a bond—that is, a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the shape of the benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.22fcd3cf-9ff6-48cf-a0d7-0cb1192e66af: Incorrect because the duration of a callable bond is not the sensitivity of the bond price to a change in the yield-to-worst (i.e., the lowest of the yield-to-maturity, yield-to-first-call, yield-to-second-call, and so forth). The problem is that future cash flows are uncertain because they are contingent on future interest rates. The issuer’s decision to call the bond depends on the ability to refinance the debt at a lower cost of funds. In brief, a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, effective duration is the appropriate duration measure. Key rate duration is not used to measure the sensitivity of a callable bond's price to a change in the yield-to-first-call.
answerFeedback.c9e6f525-053a-4317-b121-13c67d0db4ae: Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond’s own yield-to-maturity while key rate durations help identify 'shaping risk' for a bond—that is, a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the shape of the benchmark yield curve.

choices.itemBody: C. the shape of the benchmark yield curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-18
entry.itemBody: The sum of the coupon payments over a year divided by the flat price of a bond is best defined as:

answerFeedback.6f8cfef7-62ab-4583-bed1-5927cfd058ae: Incorrect because the simple yield on a bond is the sum of the coupon payments plus the straight-line amortized share of the gain or loss, divided by the flat price. The simple yield incorporates the premium and discount to maturity unlike current yield.
answerFeedback.7c6f6a8e-1b98-4145-ab4f-f65f194d5d32: Incorrect because the true yield-to-maturity is the internal rate of return on the cash flows using the actual calendar of weekends and bank holidays. True yield incorporates a bond's premium and discount to maturity unlike current yield.
answerFeedback.a34ab175-2ca1-4df5-bbad-8eeeabbf263f: Correct because the current yield (also called the income or running yield) is the sum of the coupon payments received over the year divided by the flat price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00680
entry.itemBody: An analyst is concerned that a bond might be downgraded one category by Standard & Poor's and become non-investment grade. The current rating of this bond is most likely:

answerFeedback.041cd55c-729c-40ee-a5d8-215c1797900a: Correct because BBB– is the lowest rating for investment grade bonds. A one-category downgrade (from BBB– to BB–) would make the bond non-investment grade.
answerFeedback.e18ea675-0c93-4767-af88-97d4f280f28c: Incorrect because a bond rated BB– is already below investment grade before any downgrade.
answerFeedback.e5a6999d-91fb-4419-9b20-6966ead7e92c: Incorrect because a bond rated A– can be downgraded one category (to BBB–) and still be an investment grade bond.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516054
entry.itemBody: A company that is required to raise equity capital to continue to operate as a going concern is most likely doing so to:

answerFeedback.3650a602-f6d7-468d-9a05-9cadeae4d182: Incorrect because a firm is not required to use equity capital to purchase long-lived assets. Purchasing long-lived assets is a typical use of capital for companies that are raising capital to finance revenue generating activities, but this may not be the primary reason for a firm that is forced to raise capital to continue to operate as a going concern.
answerFeedback.83c58276-a17c-4d5b-8b5e-ba0d62e32d63: Correct because in cases in which a company must raise capital to ensure it can continue to operate as a going concern, capital is most likely raised to fulfill regulatory requirements, improve capital adequacy ratios, or ensure that debt covenants are met.
answerFeedback.9915aa2c-7a07-4e52-8dca-20d0ab5ce9d4: Incorrect because a firm is not required to use equity capital to fund capital expansion projects. Funding capital expansion projects is a typical use of capital for companies that are raising capital to finance revenue generating activities, but this may not be the primary reason for a firm that is forced to raise capital to continue to operate as a going concern.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-equity-McDonald-01
entry.itemBody: An investor purchased shares on margin at €50 per share using a leverage ratio of 2.0. If the shares are sold for €70 per share, the return on the investor's equity investment is:

answerFeedback.169792fd-0368-4b6a-a9a5-b451cd7fa531: Incorrect because this ignores the leverage. The share price increased from €50 to €70 per share, (70 – 50)/50 = 40%. The leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.
answerFeedback.40a9ab1b-a600-4f2e-aa4a-4027b20fe6d2: Incorrect because this is the return if the sale price was multiplied by the leverage ratio of 2.0, instead of multiplying the % price gain by the leverage ratio. The share price increased from €50 to €70 per share, (70 – 50)/50 = 40%. Calculating €70 × 2.0 = €140, thus (140 – 50)/50 = (90/50) = 180%. The leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.
answerFeedback.a054c6ff-620c-4338-ba1f-6c018d387317: Correct because the share price increased from €50 to €70 per share, (70 – 50)/50 = 40%. The leverage ratio of 2.0 results in a return on the equity investment of 2.0 × 40% = 80%. The leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FI 06LFW
entry.itemBody: With respect to asset-backed securities, which of the following most likely redistributes prepayment risk?

answerFeedback.3d5656e4-d601-469e-8419-7cb8509056aa: Incorrect because subordination is a form of internal credit enhancement common to securitizations. Subordination is also referred to as credit tranching.
