In such a structure, there is more than one bond class or tranche, and the bond classes differ as to how they will share any losses resulting from defaults of the borrowers whose loans are in the collateral. The bond classes are classified as senior bond classes or subordinated bond classes—hence, the reason this structure is also referred to as a senior/subordinated structure.
answerFeedback.4e68855f-d19b-4bc5-9709-db4e23fd2716: Incorrect because subordination is a form of internal credit enhancement common to securitizations. subordination is also referred to as credit tranching. In such a structure, there is more than one bond class or tranche, and the bond classes differ as to how they will share any losses resulting from defaults of the borrowers whose loans are in the collateral. The bond classes are classified as senior bond classes or subordinated bond classes—hence, the reason this structure is also referred to as a senior/subordinated structure.
answerFeedback.84852b1f-5aa4-4690-9e6c-127e463a5b35: Correct because time tranching is not a credit enhancement, but a method of redistributing prepayment risk, which is different than credit risk. The purpose of time tranching is the redistribution of payments based on the timing of prepayments, regardless of the credit profile. The structure of a securitization may also allow the redistribution of another type of risk, called ‘prepayment risk’ among bond classes. Prepayment risk is the uncertainty that the cash flows will be different from the scheduled cash flows as set forth in the loan agreement because of the borrowers’ ability to alter payments, usually to take advantage of interest rate movements. The creation of bond classes that possess different expected maturities is referred to as time tranching.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606020
entry.itemBody: An investor whose portfolio lies to the right of the market portfolio on the CML most likely:

answerFeedback.88e1608b-981e-4576-8ea9-4a98e7d3a4c6: Incorrect because this portfolio will lie to the left (not right) of the market portfolio and in between the risk-free asset and the market portfolio.
answerFeedback.a78895e0-3520-4c85-8ebe-7cfa6f6700f8: Correct because a portfolio lying to the right of the market portfolio on the CML is formed by borrowing funds at the risk-free rate and investing all available funds in the market portfolio.
answerFeedback.d249fce5-cef3-4b92-a294-2aff7b99b44d: Incorrect because this portfolio will lie to the left of the market portfolio and on the intercept of the CML.

choices.itemBody: A. invested all available funds in the risk-free asset.
B. borrowed funds at the risk-free rate and invested all available funds in the market portfolio.
C. loaned some funds at the risk-free rate and invested the remaining funds in the market portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-PM-Tsependa-14
entry.itemBody: The security market line plots the expected return of a portfolio against a measure of the portfolio's:

answerFeedback.464dbdbd-9181-474f-829b-f65ed3bec544: Incorrect because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk (not total risk), on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The security market line applies to any security, efficient or not. Total risk and systematic risk are equal only for efficient portfolios because those portfolios have no diversifiable risk remaining.
answerFeedback.49e42231-5b5e-4305-a833-262c7d645c70: Incorrect because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk (not unsystematic risk), on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis.
answerFeedback.ee165bf7-6c92-4b91-8480-922447b052b9: Correct because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Glover-07
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? A standard interest rate swap has:

answerFeedback.11aed419-a5f1-476d-bfc7-9eb5b0b29653: Incorrect because other similarities between interest rate forwards and swaps include the symmetric payoff profile and the fact that no cash flow is exchanged upfront.
answerFeedback.8d7da3e1-20e2-4a20-b031-2847ca4c6ebf: Incorrect because an FRA (forward rate agreement) has a single settlement, which occurs at the beginning of an interest period, while a standard swap has periodic settlements, which occur at the end of each respective period. So, while a standard swap does have periodic settlements, these occur at the end of the period, not the beginning.
answerFeedback.d5ef93cf-02a5-4e2f-88eb-afad0c2160a5: Correct because other similarities between interest rate forwards and swaps include the symmetric payoff profile and the fact that no cash flow is exchanged upfront. The symmetric payoff profile of a swap means that the swap has zero value to both parties at contract inception.

choices.itemBody: B. the principal cash flow exchanged upfront.
C. periodic settlements that occur at the beginning of each period.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Ebeling-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is used by clearinghouses to determine the gain and loss to the parties of a futures contract?

answerFeedback.3f5a9ff9-069d-4c2f-abb5-973fe70393ab: Correct because identical contracts trade on an ongoing basis at different prices, reflecting the passage of time and the arrival of new information to the market. Thus, as the futures price changes, the parties make and lose money. Rising (falling) prices, of course, benefit (hurt) the long and hurt (benefit) the short. At the end of each day, the clearinghouse engages in a practice called mark to market, also known as the daily settlement.
answerFeedback.57d7872b-9b7b-400d-bf3b-c898359f26f3: Incorrect because some futures contracts contain a provision limiting price changes. These rules, called price limits, establish a band relative to the previous day’s settlement price, within which all trades must occur. If market participants wish to trade at a price above the upper band, trading stops, which is called limit up, until two parties agree on a trade at a price lower than the upper limit. Likewise, if market participants wish to trade at a price below the lower band, which is called limit down, no trade can take place until two parties agree to trade at a price above the lower limit. Therefore, limit up and limit down refer to price limits but not to the practice that determines current gain and loss positions of futures contract parties.
answerFeedback.8d8e42b4-6109-456b-94e8-a806d08418fa: Incorrect because if the futures price decreases, the long loses money and is charged with that loss, and the money is transferred to the account of the short. The account is specifically referred to as a margin account. A margin call is the practice for the contract party in a loss position to deposit more funds, after the loss position has been established through the daily settlement or mark to market practice.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Zhang-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about robo-advisers is most accurate?

answerFeedback.0f9feaea-dcde-412a-aaa7-8577130cf5ea: Incorrect because traditional investment advice has often underserved younger and 'mass affluent' investors with lower relative levels of investable assets. Given the efficiencies of robo-advisers and the scalability of technology, customized but standardized investment advice now can be offered to a wide range and size of investors.
answerFeedback.ae038865-f3a3-4a22-be0e-f4587a902362: Incorrect because the cost of digital investment advice provided by robo-advisers is often a fraction of traditional investment advice channels because of scalability.
answerFeedback.e75d279e-4700-45d2-8a92-2b43b5ffc7c8: Correct because, reflecting low barriers to entry, large wealth management firms have introduced robo-adviser solutions to service certain customer segments and appeal to a new generation of investors. In addition to these large wealth managers, other less-traditional entrants, such as insurance companies and asset managers, are developing solutions to cross-sell into their existing clients.

choices.itemBody: A. Robo-advisers charge higher fees than traditional investment advisers
B. Robo-advisers mainly target investors with a high level of investable assets
C. Assets managed by robo-advisers are growing in part due to new entrants such as insurance companies

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Elliott-04
entry.itemBody: Enterprise value equals the market value of a company’s debt and equity reduced by the company’s:

answerFeedback.018a1c63-26e2-41e4-af13-8d1021ea9240: Correct because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization of equity plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments).
answerFeedback.204c9768-32d3-4336-8970-30da42d56656: Incorrect because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization of equity plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments).
answerFeedback.6cee72f4-cd90-4d85-b2cb-124a783c0da8: Incorrect because enterprise value is most frequently determined as market capitalization of equity plus market value of preferred stock plus market value of debt minus cash and investments (cash equivalents and short-term investments).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02175
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate about a strong-form efficient market?

answerFeedback.00ee80d2-332f-4e3b-935d-bd2c94ce7c13: Correct because if securities markets are weak-form and semi-strong-form efficient, the implication is that active trading, whether attempting to exploit price patterns or public information, is not likely to generate abnormal returns. In other words, passive portfolio management should outperform active portfolio management. If this applies to weak-form and semi-strong form efficient markets, it applies to a strong-form efficient market as well.
answerFeedback.278a5371-ee74-4e78-9d4e-f525d0a7bffd: Incorrect because fundamental analysis is the examination of publicly available information and the formulation of forecasts to estimate the intrinsic value of assets. However, in a strong-form efficient market, security prices fully reflect both public and private information. Therefore, fundamental analysis cannot generate abnormal return in a strong-form efficient market.
answerFeedback.ef3ffa8a-6581-4f5d-b21a-2a1ac33d359e: Incorrect because in the case of a strong-form efficient market, insiders would not be able to earn abnormal returns from trading on the basis of private information. A strong-form efficient market also means that prices reflect all private information, which means that prices reflect everything that the management of a company knows about the financial condition of the company that has not been publicly released.

choices.itemBody: A. Fundamental analysis can generate abnormal returns
B. Insiders can earn abnormal returns from trading on private information
C. Passive portfolio management should outperform active portfolio management

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Garcia-Huidobro-13
entry.itemBody: Commercial paper with a face value of $25,000,000 and a term of 120 days was issued 55 days ago. If the current market value is $24,855,000, the implied discount rate assuming a 360-day year is closest to:

answerFeedback.4eb84ca6-de24-4916-93e1-b29b34457148:
Incorrect because it uses the 55 days since the commercial paper was issued instead of the 65 days remaining. Discount rate (DR) = (Year/Days) x ((FV -  PV)/FV). 

DR ≠ (360/55) x ((25,000,000 -  24,855,000)/25,000,000) = 0.037964 ≈  3.80%.
answerFeedback.715189ff-da4f-470b-9bf0-4c874c6ddc32:
Correct because Discount rate (DR) = (Year/Days) x ((FV  - PV)/FV) 

DR = (360/65) x ((25,000,000 - 24,855,000)/25,000,000) = 0.032123 ≈  3.21%.
answerFeedback.fc685386-d22c-4607-b9a9-d6e7ee080b66:
Incorrect because (FV -  PV) is divided by PV, not FV. Discount rate (DR) = (Year/Days) x ((FV -  PV)/FV). 

DR ≠ (360/65) x ((25,000,000 -  24,855,000)/24,855,000) = 0.03231 ≈  3.23%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Georgiou-23
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, a bond issuer is most likely to be evaluated as more creditworthy than its peers if it has a:

answerFeedback.676d7f8a-098c-44d8-bbe3-20fa29485501:
Correct because lower debt/EBITDA shows a lower level of debt compared to adjusted earnings and due to higher EBITDA interest coverage there is less risk that the company will not be able to pay its interest (coupon), leading to a lower probability of default and higher evaluation of creditworthiness (all else being equal).  

Debt/EBITDA is a common leverage measure. A higher ratio indicates more leverage and thus higher credit risk. Note that this ratio can be very volatile for companies with high cash flow variability, such as those in cyclical industries and with high operating leverage (fixed costs).

Coverage ratios measure an issuer’s ability to meet—to 'cover'—its interest payments. The two most common are the EBITDA/interest expense and EBIT/ interest expense ratios. The ratio EBITDA/interest expense) is a bit more liberal than the ratio EBIT/interest expense because it does not subtract out the impact of (non-cash) depreciation and amortization expense. A higher ratio indicates higher credit quality.
answerFeedback.9dd258f5-d3a3-4995-b651-92a7a5867e46: Incorrect because lower EBITDA/interest expense indicates that the company might not be able to cover its interest payments.  interest payments and thus has a higher probability of default and lower creditworthiness (all else being equal).
answerFeedback.ae32ace1-2471-40dc-b7b0-ac0ad7b6fc80: Incorrect because higher debt/EBITDA shows that there is higher leverage in comparison to earnings and this increases the probability of default and lowers the evaluation of creditworthiness of the company (all else being equal) whilst a lower EBITDA/interest expense indicates that the company might not be able to cover its interest payments.  interest payments and thus has a higher probability of default and lower creditworthiness (all else being equal).

choices.itemBody: A. lower debt/EBITDA and a lower EBITDA/interest expense.
B. lower debt/EBITDA and a higher EBITDA/interest expense.
C. higher debt/EBITDA and a lower EBITDA/interest expense.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Alt 09AXG
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a hedge fund’s fee structure:

Assets under management (AUM), beginning of period $80 million
Management fee, based on year-end AUM 2%
Incentive fee 20%

The management and incentive fees are calculated independently. If the hedge fund generates a gross return of 25%, the assets under management after fees at the end of the period are closest to:

answerFeedback.6389e5a4-e2eb-4a27-b968-4d7c635559c1: Incorrect because it is the result of multiplying the total fees plus 1 with the initial investment: Assets under management (AUM), net of fees ≠ $80 million × (1 + 20% + 2%) = $97.6 million.
answerFeedback.6a70d908-0861-4b5d-b2a2-b178d923b300:
Correct because management fee = $80 million × (1 + 25%) × 2% = $2 million;
Incentive fee = ($80 million × 25%) × 20% = $4 million;
Assets under management (AUM), net of fees = ($80 million × (1 + 25%) − $2 million − $4 million) = $94.0 million.
answerFeedback.b26c5f6b-3f8a-4161-b71d-8ecc0b3c36a6:
Incorrect because incentive fees are considered to be calculated net of management fees.
Management fee = $80 million × (1 + 25%) × 2% = $2 million;
Incentive fee ≠ (($80 million × 25%) − $2 million) × 20% = $3.6 million;
Assets under management (AUM), net of fees ≠ ($80 million × (1 + 25%) − $2 million − $3.6 million) = $94.4 million.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09104
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about two companies' non-callable, non-convertible perpetual preference shares:

  Preference Share 1 Preference Share 2
Par value $100 $100
Required rate of return 8% 11%
Annual dividend per share $6 $8

The value of Preference Share 1 is:

answerFeedback.63f4a1a2-03bc-4866-ade1-f62509dc3a37: Incorrect because the present value (PV) of Preference Share 1 is greater than the PV of Preference Share 2. That is, the present value (PV) of a non-callable, non-convertible, perpetual preference share is solved using the equation: V0 = D0 / r, where: D0 = current dividend; r = required rate of return on the stock. Therefore the PV of Preference Share 1 = $6 / 0.08% = $75.00, which is greater than the PV of Preference Share 2 = $8 / 0.11 ≈ $72.73.
answerFeedback.73e4442d-bfcd-4e1f-af9b-7c6857b1c2ba: Correct because the present value (PV) of a non-callable, non-convertible, perpetual preference share is solved using the equation: V0 = D0 /r, (where: D0 = current dividend; r = required rate of return on the stock. Therefore the PV of Preference Share 1 = $6 / 0.08 = $75.00, which is greater than the PV of Preference Share 2 = $8 / 0.11 ≈ $72.73.
answerFeedback.c8dd84cd-320d-4a96-a664-dab9335d54d6: Incorrect because the present value (PV) of Preference Share 1 is greater than the PV of Preference Share 2. That is, the present value (PV) of a non-callable, non-convertible, perpetual preference share is solved using the equation: V0 = D0 / r, where: D0 = current dividend; r = required rate of return on the stock. Therefore the PV of Preference Share 1 = $6 / 0.08 = $75.00, which is greater than the PV of Preference Share 2 = $8 / 0.11 ≈ $72.73.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the value of Preference Share 2.
B. equal to the value of Preference Share 2.
C. greater than the value of Preference Share 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Simsek-13
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information:

  Time to Maturity Yield to Maturity
Bond 1 4 years 3.3%
Bond 2 7 years 5.1%

Based only on this information, the estimated market discount rate for a 6-year bond with similar credit quality is:

answerFeedback.1b415a55-307f-4dc4-8d93-f9b3cb19b69a: Correct because some fixed-rate bonds are not actively traded. Therefore, there is no market price available to calculate the rate of return required by investors. In these situations, it is common to estimate the market discount rate and price based on the quoted or flat prices of more frequently traded comparable bonds. These comparable bonds have similar times-to-maturity, coupon rates, and credit quality. This estimation process is called matrix pricing. The estimated market discount rate can be obtained with linear interpolation. Using linear interpolation between the two given bonds, we have: 0.033 + (6 – 4) / (7 – 4) × (0.051 – 0.033) = 0.033 + 2 / 3 × 0.018 = 0.045 = 4.5%.
answerFeedback.78a6478e-686e-4d5e-b504-08b4dbc6258c: Incorrect this response is an incorrect application of matrix pricing, where the estimated market discount rate can be obtained with linear interpolation. This response is incorrect because it is the simple average of the two given bonds: (0.033 + 0.051) / 2 = 0.084 / 2 = 0.042 = 4.2%.
answerFeedback.dd552882-aaa1-4b5e-b9b1-f5486ef0bcfd: Incorrect this response is an incorrect application of matrix pricing, where the estimated market discount rate can be obtained with linear interpolation. This response is incorrect because it uses linear interpolation from the wrong end between the two given bonds: 0.033 + (7 – 6) / (7 – 4) × (0.051 – 0.033) = 0.033 + 1 / 3 × 0.018 = 0.039 = 3.9%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601003
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements best describes changes in the value of a long forward position during its life?

answerFeedback.2e5ce58e-04b7-4ceb-9941-2ce8ac6eccd0:
Correct because given the formula for the value of a forward contract:

Vt(T) = St – F0(T)(1 + r)–(T–t ) it follows that the value of the contract goes up as the price of the underlying goes up.
answerFeedback.35121285-a1ea-42d8-a04f-c08d7ab3cf2e: Incorrect because as the time to maturity goes down, the value of the contract goes down.
answerFeedback.fa85aac9-52c2-4071-9f33-8d97f55cfbf6: Incorrect because as interest rates go down, the value of the contract goes down.

choices.itemBody: A. As interest rates go down, the value of the position goes up
B. As the time to maturity goes down, the value of the position goes up
C. As the price of the underlying goes up, the value of the position goes up

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-14
entry.itemBody: A reason for a company's management to repurchase its shares is to signal a belief that the company's shares are:

answerFeedback.22897f26-e4ba-4a5e-bee9-14085031f9a7: Incorrect because company managements have expressed several key reasons for engaging in share repurchases— namely, signaling a belief that their shares are undervalued, not overvalued.
answerFeedback.2795b713-690e-4503-af54-adfdc90af818: Incorrect because company managements have expressed several key reasons for engaging in share repurchases— namely, signaling a belief that their shares are undervalued, not fairly valued.
answerFeedback.e59607e8-3de5-413b-832d-18f3d749f21e: Correct because company managements have expressed several key reasons for engaging in share repurchases— namely, signaling a belief that their shares are undervalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07360
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following estimates about a company:

Earnings retention rate 40%
Growth rate 3%

If the justified forward P/E is 10 based on the Gordon growth model, the required rate of return is:

answerFeedback.1190c881-b22b-48d3-b287-ed3cec01d219: Correct because 9% is the required rate of return (r), determined by rearranging the justified forward P/E ratio to solve for r, which requires first calculating the dividend payout ratio. The dividend payout ratio = (1 ‒ earnings retention rate) = (1 – 0.40) = 0.60. The justified forward P/E = (D1 / E1) / (r–g) = p / (r – g) = 10. Rearranging the equation: r = p / (P/E) + g = (0.6 / 10) + 0.03 = 0.09 = 9%, where P0 = current intrinsic value, E1 = forecast for next year's earnings, p = dividend payout ratio, g = growth rate.
answerFeedback.42dc9d10-f771-4db0-a643-df16e9ea57f9:
Incorrect because it is the result when the retention rate is substituted for the payout rate:

r = p / 10 + g = 0.4 / 10 + 0.03 = 0.07 = 7%.
answerFeedback.b7e7445a-dd37-43f8-8ccd-623400a06f14: Incorrect because it is the result when the second term, g, is omitted: r = p / 10 + g = 0.6 / 10 + 0 = 0.06 = 6%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely considered an affirmative covenant?

answerFeedback.2941c3b1-5792-447e-a15b-f9ec85ad1d9c: Correct because this is an affirmative covenant. Bondholders have limited influence over an issuer as compared to equity investors, who have voting rights. One exception to this is legally enforceable rules or bond covenants that borrowers and lenders agree on at the time a bond is issued or a loan is made. Affirmative covenants specify what issuers are required to do, whereas negative covenants specify what issuers are prohibited from doing. Affirmative covenants are typically administrative in nature. For example, common affirmative covenants include the use of proceeds from the bond issue, the provision of timely financial reports, and permitting bondholders to redeem their bonds at a premium to par if the issuer is acquired.
answerFeedback.611c795f-7eac-4ea5-886a-8d4d73914ca6: Incorrect because this is a negative covenant. Bondholders are protected by a set of covenants which closely monitor certain financial ratios and restrict its ability to pay dividends to shareholders, repurchase shares, and / or take on additional debt. Negative covenants include limitations on investments, the disposal of assets, or issuance of debt senior to existing obligations under what is known as a negative pledge clause. Negative covenants seek to ensure that an issuer maintains the ability to make interest and principal payments.
answerFeedback.733081fc-52e1-4a31-8266-a20ea0271487: Incorrect because this is a negative covenant. Bondholders are protected by a set of covenants which closely monitor certain financial ratios and restrict its ability to pay dividends to shareholders, repurchase shares, and / or take on additional debt.

choices.itemBody: B. A limit on the level of share buybacks
C. What the issuer will do with the proceeds of a bond issue

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Erickson-24
entry.itemBody: The actions of non-hedging investors impact:

answerFeedback.65a4af12-6732-4829-b6f9-92c2365947a5:
Incorrect because non-hedging investors can also affect demand for commodities.

Demand for commodities is determined by the needs of end users and secondarily by the actions of non-hedging investors.
answerFeedback.9e60dc8f-b61c-415e-b6a2-955d516e02fd: Correct because supplies of physical commodities are determined by production and inventory levels and secondarily by the actions of non-hedging investors. Demand for commodities is determined by the needs of end users and secondarily by the actions of non-hedging investors.
answerFeedback.c4d235b0-9ff4-45f7-b913-90c09bc1303f:
Incorrect because non-hedging investors can also affect supply of commodities. 

Supplies of physical commodities are determined by production and inventory levels and secondarily by the actions of non-hedging investors.

choices.itemBody: C. both commodity supply and commodity demand.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516030
entry.itemBody: Accounting standards and reporting requirements that produce meaningful and timely financial disclosures are most critical for achieving which of the following efficiencies associated with a well-functioning financial system?

answerFeedback.5fd2625b-ba11-4067-b5bb-dc2935abe7d3: Incorrect. Allocational efficiency refers to making resources available where they are most valuable.
answerFeedback.7a489bff-29ac-43c6-a53d-ecb7add7520e: Correct. Accounting standards and reporting requirements that allow meaningful and timely financial disclosures reduce the costs of obtaining fundamental information and thereby allow analysts to form more accurate estimates of fundamental values. They support informationally efficient markets.
answerFeedback.8abd44e0-5512-41f3-b99b-ff05414be385: Incorrect. Operational efficiency relates to the costs of arranging trades, which can be reduced via organized exchanges, brokerages, securitization, clearing houses, and so forth.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03838
entry.itemBody: At initiation, the price of a forward contract is most likely:

answerFeedback.60372c61-df82-4ec1-ae7f-90ee219f3ba3: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, the price of a forward contract at initiation is not equal to the value of the forward contract.
answerFeedback.68789616-7030-4879-af5e-8a712534b575: Incorrect because, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, the price of a forward contract at initiation is not less than the value of the forward contract.
answerFeedback.9b30c7a2-d64d-425c-82cb-20ae587b0899: Correct because neither the long nor the short pays anything to the other at the initiation date of a forward contract, the value of a forward contract when initiated is zero. On the other hand, the forward price that the parties agree to at the initiation date of the contract is a special price that results in the contract having zero value and prohibiting arbitrage. As this price agreed by the parties is a positive number, the price of a forward contract at initiation is greater than the value of the contract, which is zero.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the value of the forward contract.
B. equal to the value of the forward contract.
C. greater than the value of the forward contract.

entry.title: ITEM_20190531001
entry.itemBody: An asset-backed securitization with a waterfall structure is most likely structured with which type of credit enhancement?

answerFeedback.1e531648-35b3-4c75-b2e0-920e9cf6f5f8: Incorrect. An SPE is a bankruptcy remote legal entity that holds the collateral and is considered not an enhancement but, rather, a prerequisite for establishing securitizations.
answerFeedback.7494c8d4-93f5-4789-a565-36f644e3649b: Correct. Asset-backed securitizations can be structured with subordinated bond classes. They function as credit protection for the more senior bond classes; that is, losses are realized by the subordinated bond classes before any losses are realized by the senior bond classes. This type of protection is also commonly referred to as a waterfall structure because of the cascading flow of payments between bond classes in the event of default.
answerFeedback.e85f261b-5077-494f-be6f-dd697d0f2901: Incorrect. The creation of bond classes that possess different expected maturities is referred to as time tranching.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 04DJE
entry.itemBody: Failed market regulation most likely results in decreased:

answerFeedback.32c90b9b-b5ad-4a10-8919-178587836040: Correct because economies that cannot solve regulatory problems tend to operate less efficiently than do better regulated economies, and they tend to be less wealthy.
answerFeedback.c296ba6a-89d3-4182-98ee-36a15582f352: Incorrect because financial markets tend to be complex, and because customers are often much less sophisticated than the professionals that serve them, the potential for losses through various frauds can be unacceptably high in unregulated markets.
answerFeedback.e386a805-0157-4474-8ac3-50b36a723108: Incorrect because regulation is necessary because regulating certain behaviors through market-based mechanisms is too costly for people who are unsophisticated and uninformed.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Lee-05
entry.itemBody: Under which of the following alternative investment methods can an investor invest indirectly in alternative assets?

answerFeedback.7ed99ca0-1444-4d08-a856-356d25ef24f5: Incorrect because under co-investing, the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets.
answerFeedback.ab7aacd0-a452-44da-88ca-9f0a38c95ee8: Correct because fund investing can be viewed as an indirect method of investing in alternative assets. In addition, under co-investing, the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets.
answerFeedback.e2cbcc4e-91e6-4e54-a2a4-45cabeb3161c: Incorrect because fund investing can be viewed as an indirect method of investing in alternative assets. In addition, under co-investing, the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606082
entry.itemBody:
Information for Stock A and the market appear in the following table:

Standard deviation of Stock A's return 40%
Standard deviation of the market's return 20%
Correlation of Stock A with the market 85%

The beta of Stock A is closest to:

answerFeedback.2c3825d6-5305-4a08-bff3-a9070993bcc7:
Correct. Beta, β, of a stock is calculated as:

 

β = ρi,mσi ÷ σm

 

where

  • ρi,m = correlation of the stock with the market

  • σi = standard deviation of the stock

  • σm = standard deviation of the market

 

Plugging in the numbers

 β = 0.85×0.40÷0.20 = 1.70.
answerFeedback.2f703cb0-433e-4763-929a-3d148394b04d: Incorrect because this calculation incorrectly swaps the standard deviation of the market and the standard deviation of the stock between the numerator and denominator: 0.85 × 0.20÷0.40 = 0.43
answerFeedback.cd1d5e0c-827f-425d-ac27-54347977b469: Incorrect because this calculation incorrectly puts the correlation in the denominator: 0.4÷(0.2×0.85) = 2.35.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516164
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a cross-sectional anomaly in financial markets?

answerFeedback.0ed147f0-e068-4bba-a20a-f5c347d23ea7: Correct because the value effect—that is, stocks with below-average price-to-earnings and market-to-book ratios and above-average dividend yields have consistently outperformed growth stocks over long periods—is a cross-sectional anomaly.
answerFeedback.2cd20076-3fc6-4fb3-8c56-49330fe17615: Incorrect because the overreaction effect is a time-series anomaly, not a cross-sectional anomaly.
answerFeedback.85a53c72-8a8c-4760-a251-ccf910d928f3: Incorrect because a closed-end fund discount is an anomaly where a closed-end fund trades at a discount from its net asset value. It is not a cross-sectional anomaly.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-01
entry.itemBody: Compared to investing in a single security, the portfolio approach can improve investors' risk–return trade-off by offering:

answerFeedback.1069a273-71ae-4403-95af-52c3ccce7c8e: Incorrect because in addition to avoiding a potential disaster associated with over investing in a single security, portfolios also generally offer equivalent expected returns with lower overall volatility of returns—as represented by a measure such as standard deviation.
answerFeedback.408315c8-fb99-4054-a0ab-1e8b0464cbef: Incorrect because in addition to avoiding a potential disaster associated with over investing in a single security, portfolios also generally offer equivalent expected returns with lower (not higher) overall volatility of returns—as represented by a measure such as standard deviation. One of the critical ideas about portfolios: Portfolios affect risk more than returns.
answerFeedback.ee3cef55-5c80-414d-ae82-c23b4f651a7e: Correct because in addition to avoiding a potential disaster associated with over investing in a single security, portfolios also generally offer equivalent expected returns with lower overall volatility of returns—as represented by a measure such as standard deviation. One of the critical ideas about portfolios: Portfolios affect risk more than returns.

choices.itemBody: A. lower expected return with the same overall volatility of returns.
B. the same expected return with lower overall volatility of returns.
C. higher overall volatility of returns for a given level of expected return.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607077
entry.itemBody: In a rising interest rate environment, the effective duration of a putable bond relative to an otherwise identical non-putable bond, will most likely be:

answerFeedback.1a358194-6013-40c2-aeb4-aed96a004398: Incorrect because in a rising interest rate environment the effective duration of a putable bond will be lower than the effective duration of a comparable non-putable bond.
answerFeedback.47ab7500-d7ee-46f9-9ab3-8f450894bbc1: Incorrect because in a rising interest rate environment the effective duration of a putable bond will be lower, not higher, than the effective duration of a comparable non-putable bond.
answerFeedback.e6b9973e-b14f-4ac5-968f-bfda9ab3ecbc: Correct because when interest rates are rising, the put option becomes more valuable to the investor. The ability to sell the bond at par value limits the price depreciation as rates rise. So, the presence of an embedded put option reduces the sensitivity of the bond price to changes in interest rates, resulting in a lower effective duration.
